Description: Egyptian terracotta of Athena figure wearing an Attic peplos and an aegis with a central gorgoneion as clasp. Mould-made, arms added later and subsequently lost. Traces of soft white (gypsum) coating without any trace of paint left. Nile silt brown fabric with black core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, clay pellets and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Orgininally ascribed a classical date, but technique and fabri onsitent with the Naukratis terracottas workshop dated 3rd to 2nd century BC. Depiction of the goddess Athena wearing an Attic peplos and an aegis with a central gorgoneion as clasp. This is a common representation of Athena since the mid to late 5th century BC, but here represented on a Ptolemaic figurine.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.245) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, no. 124)
